subNodes.conversationText: root
The mound of soil over the corpse looked rich and moist. The tomatoes were very red.
To begin the planting, <FirstName> would need the trowel Eldest Lady mentioned.
<FirstName> dug a hole in the soil.
<FirstName> didn't have the seed, though.
<He/She> would have to get it from the table.
<FirstName> placed the seed in the hole and covered it with loose soil.
Now <he/she> needed to water it. <He/She> would have to bring the pitcher of water from the table.
<FirstName> poured the water from the pitcher.
The soil drank it eagerly. As <FirstName> watched, <he/she> heard the witches chanting from the house:
[Continue.]

"More or less, less or more.
Death's a house without a door.
Life's a squatter, rank and poor.
More or less, less or more."
[Continue.]
A shoot emerged, then a vine, and then an unfurling of leaves and buds and orange flowers. One flower was so big it rose up and covered the sun.
[Continue.]
It wilted and fell like drapery over something upright on the grave. The object was about as tall as <FirstName> but far bulkier. The witches were silent. <FirstName> felt their eyes on <him/her>.
<He/She> tore away the fallen flower.
Shreds fell. Beneath was an organic wall of mottled green and great yellow ridges.
[Continue.]

The object moved. The rest of the flower fell away. In its place stood an almost human figure dressed in a burlap jacket and carrying a staff. Its chest rose and fell, but it made no sound of breathing. How could it? It had no eyes, no ears, no nose, no mouth. It was a giant gourd.

The witches came out of the house.
[Continue.]
"This is our gift to you. His name is Knott. He'll protect you."
[Folk Magic] <FirstName> stared, aghast, at the being before <him/her>. <He/She> had doubted that magic of this sort was possible.
Eldest Lady saw <his/her> wonder. "I am called 'Eldest Lady' for a reason. I do more than give bad winds to sailors and backaches to farmers."
[Continue.]
"She also gives sweet milk to cats and stern commands to dogs."
[Continue.]
"So I do: Shut up, Puppy."
"You said its name is Knott?"
"Yes. His name."
"What is this creature?"
"I do not need such a servant."
"It grew from the dead witch's grave. Is it --?"
<FirstName> accepted the witch's gift.
[Folk Magic] <FirstName> stared, aghast, at the being before <him/her>. <He/She> had doubted that magic of this sort was possible.
Eldest Lady saw <his/her> wonder. "I am called 'Eldest Lady' for a reason. I do more than give bad winds to sailors and backaches to farmers."
[Folk Magic] <FirstName> stared, aghast, at the being before <him/her>. <He/She> had doubted that magic of this sort was possible.
Eldest Lady saw <his/her> wonder. "I am called 'Eldest Lady' for a reason. I do more than give bad winds to sailors and backaches to farmers."
[Folk Magic] <FirstName> stared, aghast, at the being before <him/her>. <He/She> had doubted that magic of this sort was possible.
Eldest Lady saw <his/her> wonder. "I am called 'Eldest Lady' for a reason. I do more than give bad winds to sailors and backaches to farmers."
[Folk Magic] <FirstName> stared, aghast, at the being before <him/her>. <He/She> had doubted that magic of this sort was possible.
Eldest Lady saw <his/her> wonder. "I am called 'Eldest Lady' for a reason. I do more than give bad winds to sailors and backaches to farmers."
"Knott? That's its name?"
"Yes. His name."
[Continue.]
"A male gourd -- but, alas, vegetable from head to foot."
[Continue.]
"He lacks the milk of human kindness."
[Continue.]
"And the milk of animal kindness," said Middle One in a pained tone.
"I do not need such a servant."
"It grew from the dead witch's grave. Is it --?"
<FirstName> accepted the witch's gift.
"What is this creature?"
"A gourd, more or less. One with legs and hands and a rough sort of intelligence."
[Continue.]
"A male gourd -- but, alas, vegetable from head to foot."
"I do not need such a servant."
The witches laughed.
[Continue.]
"Who does need a walking gourd?"
[Continue.]
"We do, Middle One. We'd like our new witch to live long enough to join the coven."
"What kind of creature is he?"
"A gourd, more or less. One with legs and hands and a rough sort of intelligence."
"It grew from the dead witch's grave. Is it --?"
"I suppose I have no choice."

Eldest Lady nodded. "Let him be your shield."

Knott has joined your party.
[Continue.]
"It grew from the dead witch's grave. Is it --?"
"No, no. She's dead and gone. But a witch in a grave is still a witch in a way, until the world reclaims her body completely. Knott couldn't have grown on a parson's grave."
[Continue.]
"Or a peasant's. Or a pheasant's. Or a cook's, haberdasher's, turkey's, jailor's --"
[Continue.]
"Enough, Middle One."
"What kind of creature is he?"
"I do not need such a servant."
<FirstName> accepted the witch's gift.
<FirstName> accepted the witch's gift.

"Good, good. Let him be your shield."

Knott has joined your party.
[Continue.]
"His rind is thicker than yours."
[Continue.]

"The woods are dangerous. Not just hunters, understand. The Congress of Moths is here, too."

Pharaoh croaked.
"The Congress of Moths? Here? Why?"
"Who knows? Their malice is fickle. Their flights know no season."
[Continue.]
"More or less."
[Continue.]
"Quiet, Middle One." The reprimand was sharp.
[Continue.]
"I only meant to say," said Middle One, "that the Children might have come to plague the woods because of our sister's murder."
[Continue.]

Eldest Lady appeared to consider this.

"Perhaps... But it's useless making guesses about them. Be a good example for and talk less."
"What is the Congress of Moths, exactly?"
"And you call yourself a witch! They are the Children of the Wooden Crone. Folk who know less call them fairies."
"I'm ready. I'll be careful."
"Good. What's today's date, Middle One?"
"The Congress of Moths? They are real, then?"
"And you call yourself a witch! They are the Children of the Wooden Crone. Folk who know less call them fairies."
[Continue.]
"Mockers, turncoats, monsters, cutthroats. Lovely little things."
[Continue.]
UNUSED
[Continue.]
"They tear us to pieces."
"And why are they here?"
"Who knows? Their malice is fickle. Their flights know no season."
"And why are they here?"
"I'm ready. I'll be careful."
"We'll be careful."
"Good. What's today's date, Middle One?"
[Continue.]
"July 26th. Morning. The breeze is in the southeast, and I anticipate fine weather for the next week."
[Continue.]
"Good. The season favors you. Return to us with the hunter's blood by the end of the month. Do not dawdle."
"What happens if I take longer?"

"Then you fail. Our sabbath begins at midnight on the first of August, and the blood must bind you to us then or never. If you fail, we'll have to wait another year to complete the coven with someone else."
"Then I'll not fail."
"You are free to return if you need food or rest. I'll see you again in five days' time."
"Very well."
"Very well."
"You are free to return if you need food or rest. I'll see you again in five days' time."
[Continue.]

The three of them went into the house. Knott followed close behind. The two older witches said farewell to <FirstName>, and soon <he/she> was standing outside. The grim walking gourd stood beside <him/her>. Pharaoh eyed the forest.
This wasn't at all what <FirstName> had expected.
<His/Her> preconceptions seemed naive.
<He/She> had imagined soft-spoken mentors who'd keep a teapot going and pass on wisdom in mild tones.
Eldest Lady and Middle One had not offered tea to <FirstName>.
[Continue.]

Instead, had been roughly welcomed, ordered to procure the blood of a murderer, and cast into peril.

looked at the late July sun and how it lit the meadows through which had come. looked at the woods and the night still lingering there. Then set off.
[End.]
[End.]
<He/She> had imagined the coven would be more -- perfunctory, a light obligation to endure as <he/she> learned.
<He/She> had even hoped the witches might recognize <his/her> talent and treat <him/her> as an equal.
[Continue.]

Instead, had been roughly welcomed, ordered to procure the blood of a murderer, and cast into peril.

looked at the late July sun and how it lit the meadows through which had come. looked at the woods and the night still lingering there. Then set off.
<He/She> had imagined a large coven full of beautiful young people.
There would be songs under starlight, midsummer revels, little jealousies and passions. <He/She> would be sung to, asked to dance, kissed.
[Continue.]

Instead, had been roughly welcomed, ordered to procure the blood of a murderer, and cast into peril.

looked at the late July sun and how it lit the meadows through which had come. looked at the woods and the night still lingering there. Then set off.
<FirstName> had tried not to form expectations about the witches.
The Wooden Crone, after all, delighted in upsetting expectations.
Still, it was hard not to recall <his/her> daydreams.
Perhaps comparing these fantasies with the truth would be instructive.
<He/She> had imagined soft-spoken mentors who'd keep a teapot going and pass on wisdom in mild tones.
<He/She> had imagined the coven would be more -- perfunctory, a light obligation to endure as <he/she> learned.
<He/She> had imagined a large coven full of beautiful young people.
Meanwhile, <FirstName> had never become attached to extravagant hopes.
For the moment, at least, <he/she> and the Wooden Crone had an excellent understanding... Then <FirstName> checked <him/her>self. The Crone was not to be understood.
[Continue.]
<He/She> looked at the late July sun and how it lit the meadows through which <he/she> had come. <He/She> looked at the woods and the night still lingering there. Then <he/she> set off.
<FirstName> was ready to begin.
<He/She> looked at the late July sun and how it lit the meadows through which <he/she> had come. <He/She> looked at the woods and the night still lingering there. Then <he/she> set off.
[End.]
<He/She> looked at the late July sun and how it lit the meadows through which <he/she> had come. <He/She> looked at the woods and the night still lingering there. Then <he/she> set off.
[End.]
<He/She> waited.
The drapery shriveled. Beneath, <FirstName> could see mottled green and yellow.
[Continue.]
[Leave.]
The grave was ready for the witches' seed, but <FirstName> didn't have it.
<FirstName> brought out the witches' seed.
<FirstName> placed the seed in the hole and covered it with loose soil.
The seed was ready for water, but <FirstName> didn't have it.
<FirstName> poured the water from the pitcher.
The soil drank it eagerly. As <FirstName> watched, <he/she> heard the witches chanting from the house:
<FirstName> left the grave alone.
<FirstName> returned to the grave.
To begin the planting, <FirstName> would need the trowel Eldest Lady mentioned.
<FirstName> dug a hole in the soil.
The grave was ready for the witches' seed, but <FirstName> didn't have it.
<FirstName> brought out the witches' seed.
